map_node.indicator_description: The percent of streets with bike lanes can affect cyclist and pedestrian safety, physical activity, and sustainable transportation use.

dataset.display: Percent of Streets with Bicycle Lanes
dataset.measure: Percent of Streets with Bicycle Lanes
dataset.how_calculated: Percentage of streets with bicycle lanes (conventional and protected bicycle lanes, excluding sharrows, dirt trails, boardwalks, and velodrome tracks).
dataset.discription: New York City Department of Transportation
dataset.legend_title: Percent of Streets with Bicycle Lanes

show_disparities_node.disparitiesPagetext: When population health or the quality of living environments varies by population characteristics such as income or race, there is disparity. One way to visualize disparity is to chart indicators of health or environment across levels of neighborhood poverty. We categorized neighborhoods as high, medium or low poverty. Then we took the median of the neighborhood-specific values in each category. The median is the middle of the sorted group of values.

show_disparities_data.Measure: Percent of Streets with Bicycle Lanes

Link.y_axis_title: Percent of Streets with Bicycle Lanes  (Median of Neighborhoods)

info.info_measure: Percent of Streets with Bicycle Lanes
info.info_how_calculated: Percentage of streets with bicycle lanes (conventional and protected bicycle lanes, excluding sharrows, dirt trails, boardwalks, and velodrome tracks).
info.info_source: New York City Department of Transportation

info.info_how_calculated: Neighborhoods are ranked according to the percent of people whose annual income falls below 100% of the federal poverty level. Rankings are then divided into 3 approximately equal groupings of low, medium and high poverty.

summarize_data.indicator_description: The percent of streets with bike lanes can affect cyclist and pedestrian safety, physical activity, and sustainable transportation use.
